metadata.title: Coating-boosted interfacial thermal transport for carbon nanotube array nano-thermal interface materials

sections.text:
Accepted Manuscript
Coating-boosted interfacial thermal transport for carbon nanotube array nano-thermal interface materials Lin Qiu, Pu Guo, Qinyu Kong, Chong Wei Tan, Kun Liang, Jun Wei, Ju Nie Tey, Yanhui Feng, Xinxin Zhang, Beng Kang Tay
PII: S0008-6223(19)30088-0 DOI: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.carbon.2019.01.085 Reference: CARBON 13889
To appear in: Carbon
Received Date: 9 April 2018 Revised Date: 3 January 2019 Accepted Date: 24 January 2019
Please cite this article as: L. Qiu, P. Guo, Q. Kong, C.W. Tan, K. Liang, J. Wei, J.N. Tey, Y. Feng, X. Zhang, B.K. Tay, Coating-boosted interfacial thermal transport for carbon nanotube array nano-thermal interface materials, Carbon (2019), doi: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.carbon.2019.01.085.

The manuscript will undergo copyediting, typesetting, and review of the resulting proof before it is published in its final form. Coating-boosted interfacial thermal transport for carbon nanotube array
nano-thermal interface materials Lin Qiu1,2, Pu Guo1,2, Qinyu Kong3, Chong Wei Tan3, Kun Liang3, Jun Wei4, Ju Nie Tey5, Yanhui Feng1,2*, Xinxin Zhang1,2, Beng Kang Tay3,6* 1School of Energy and Environmental Engineering, University of Science and Technology Beijing, Beijing 100083, China 2Beijing Key Laboratory of Energy Saving and Emission Reduction for Metallurgical Industry, University of Science and Technology Beijing, Beijing 100083, China 3Center for Micro/Nano-electronics (NOVITAS), School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, 50 Nanyang Avenue, Singapore 639798, Singapore 4Structural Electronics Programme, Singapore institute of Manufacturing Technology,73 Nanyang Drive, Singapore 637662 5Large Area Processing Programme, Singapore institute of Manufacturing Technology, 73 Nanyang Drive, Singapore 637662 6CINTRA UMI CNRS/NTU/THALES 3288, Research Techno Plaza, 50 Nanyang Drive, Border X Block, Level 6, Singapore 637553, Singapore *Corresponding authors. E-mail: yhfeng@me.ustb.edu.cn (Yanhui Feng), BKTAY@ntu.edu.sg (Beng Kang Tay)
ABSTRACT The interfacial thermal transport (ITT) between vertically aligned carbon nanotube (VACNT) arrays and heat sink is the dominant barrier blocking the path towards practical application of VACNT arrays as nano-thermal interface materials (nTIMs). Although developing VACNT arrays with homogeneous heights and larger diameters could lower the thermal contact resistance between the arrays and heat sink (Rc), little effect is achieved at present stage. Here, by using Plasma Enhanced Chemical Vapor Deposition approach, we attain DLC/TiN-coated VACNT arrays, which gives up to 50 times reduction in Rc from 15 mm 2 K/W to 0.3 mm2 K/W. Microscopic morphological analyses confirm that the remarkably expanded contact area brought by coatings can promote the ITT and also retain the high phonon transmission rate within individual CNTs. These novel structures are significantly in favor of fulfilling a nTIM function. It is also intriguing to note that Rc is no longer linearly dependent on CNT height variations once CNT diameters become large
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
enough. This indicates that the contact area with heat sink is dominant in influencing Rc instead of the surface roughness. The above findings fuel future effort towards industrial realization of high-performance VACNT array-based nTIM and high-efficiency thermal management in microelectronic and nanoenergy fields.
KEYWORDS: Diamond like carbon coating · Nano-thermal interface materials · Vertically aligned carbon nanotube array · Titanium nitride coating · Thermal contact resistance

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Since its discovery, vertically aligned carbon nanotube (VACNT) arrays have exhibited
unique advantages as nano-thermal interface materials (nTIMs) for integrated circuit packaging and electronic cooling.[1-6] Ultra-high thermal conductivity (κ), highly ordered orientation and adaptable morphology to the roughness of the contact surface enable CNT to become an ideal thermal conductive filler, which surpasses the disadvantages of commercial silicone grease such as frequently incurred leakage, contamination to electronic devices and limited κ value. However, it is still challenging to attain large-scale application of VACNT arrays because of a dominant thermal transport barrier caused by the uneven height of VACNTs.[7-9] This barrier is generally described as the thermal contact resistance (Rc) between VACNT array and heat sink.[10,11] A series of work focusing on the reduction of Rc for VACNT arrays have been consistently reported, shedding light on its potential for efficient heat dissipation application. Metallic bonding with Ti/Au/In/Sn on free-end VACNT tips is proven a feasible approach to achieve a Rc reduction. Experimental measurements elucidate that Rc can be shrunk to 1~3.5 mm 2 K/W, nearly an order of magnitude smaller than that of the non-bonding counterpart (10~16 mm2 K/W).[4,12-14] A recent progress has been
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
reported on the successful bridging between metal surfaces and VACNT arrays where short, covalently bonded cysteamine and aminopropyl-trialkoxy-silane molecules demonstrate that Rc for VACNT array-gold and VACNT array-aluminium interfaces can be reduced to 0.8 and 0.6 mm2 K/W, respectively.[15] This minimized Rc is nearly equivalent to the thermal resistance of VACNT arrays (0.1~0.4 mm2 K/W for VACNT height of approximately 10 µm).[8,16] To attain to this, a series of complicated chemical functionalization processes are required. Therefore, the quest to find better approaches to reduce Rc for VACNT array-based nTIM is still on-going. In pursuit of a new strategy for boosting interfacial thermal transport (ITT) between VACNT array and heat sink, we endeavor to investigate a possible optimum method to improve the interface contact conditions for VACNT array-heat sink structures in this work.
Previous studies have found that Rc is strongly dependent on the VACNT array top
roughness and effective contact area with the heat sink. Specifically, the array top roughness originates from the CNT’s height variation and the contact area is determined by CNT’s diameters. Therefore, CNT arrays with homogeneous heights and larger diameters generally render lower Rc, owing to the decreased roughness and increased contact area with the heat sink,[8] shedding light on the potential for improving the ITT between CNT arrays and heat sink. In the light of the limited enhancement of ITT through optimizing the growth conditions,[9,16] we are seeking for better approaches by coating the top of the VACNT array with nanofilms, with the purpose of enlarging the contact areas between the array and heat sink and reducing the height variation of the CNTs. In this study, we have successfully developed VACNT arrays coated with diamond-like carbon (DLC, defined as amorphous carbon with higher than 70% sp3 bonds) and titanium nitride (TiN) nanofilms to achieve experimentally an extremely low Rc at CNT-heat sink interface. This aims to shrink the Rc after applying VACNT array as nTIM between heat spreader and microelectronic devices
M AN
US
CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
(Fig. 1).
Fig. 1. Coatings remarkably reducing thermal contact resistance (Rc) for VACNT array nTIM.
2. Experimental 2.1 Sample preparation
Vertically aligned multi-walled CNT (MWCNT) arrays which serves as a platform for
investigating the tunable Rc were successfully synthesized based on an Aixtron Blackmagic Plasma Enhanced Chemical Vapor Deposition (PECVD) approach.[17,18] In brief, a 20 nm thick Ni catalyst layer was e-beam evaporated onto a diced SiO2/Si substrate (length × width: 1 cm × 1 cm, thickness: 525 µm/380 nm). The whole substrate was placed in a vacuum chamber with pressure of 5 mbar. A radio frequency electric field was applied and biased at 700 V in the chamber with a plasma power of 90 W. A 10 min pre-growth annealing process with NH3 flow of 250 standard-state cubic centimeter per minute (sccm) under 625°C was performed to promote Ni film decomposing into nanoclusters (NCs) islands in a scattered distribution. Next, the introduction of NH3/C2H2 flow at 250/50 sccm started the CNTs growth process at 750°C for 30 mins.
Titanium nitride (TiN) and diamond-like carbon (DLC) films were deposited by filtered
cathodic vacuum arc (FCVA) technique.[19-21] These two common wear-resistant coating materials have high hardness and high elastic recovery rate,[20,21] which can help protect the
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
array structure from external damage and improve the service life. In addition to mechanical properties, they also possess excellent chemical corrosion resistance properties, electrical properties and thermal stability. With regard to the preparation process, the other coating methods are implemented by means of transferring CNT arrays between different substrates using catalysts to metallize the ends of the CNT. The DLC and TiN coating techniques have been relatively matured,[19-21] which is more attractive compared with the complicated functionalization or metallization processes. For TiN deposition, a circular titanium plate (diameter: 90 mm, purity: 99.99%) as the cathodic arc source was used to produce Ti plasma under a DC bias current of 110 A. The plasma was then guided into the processing chamber (base pressure: 2×10-5 Pa) by the electromagnetic field through a 90º pipe bended filter, which was biased to 20 V voltage and wrapped with solenoid coils outside to ensure that the plasma is centered at the axial position of the filter. The TiN was deposited at a constant negative DC bias voltage of -200 V under a nitrogen pressure of 0.2 Pa for 20 and 30 mins, respectively. To deposit a smooth DLC films, the high-density arc plasma under a DC bias current of 100 A was applied while a graphite target was irradiated under argon gas. The VACNT array was subjected to a DC bias voltage of -350 kV for DLC deposition for 15, 30, 45 and 60 mins, respectively. For both TiN and DLC depositions, the unwanted neutral particles and macroparticles were removed by the filter duct as the Lorentz force had no influence on these uncharged particles.
2.2 Morphological characterization
A Hitachi S-4800 scanning electron microscope (SEM, FEI, Tokyo, Japan) was used to
characterize the morphologies and sizes of the VACNT arrays. A JEOL JEM-2100F field emission high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM, FEI, Hillsboro, USA) was employed to perform high-resolution morphology analysis of the TiN/DLC-coated CNTs
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
as well as selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern analysis. Raman spectra of VACNT arrays under different conditions were measured using an inVia-Reflex confocal Raman spectroscope (Renishaw, UK). Three excitation wavelengths of 532 nm (2.44 eV, Diode laser), 633 nm (2.05 eV, Diode laser) and 785 nm (1.66 eV, Diode laser) were used in the backscattering geometry. The laser power density projected to the surface of the sample was approximately 108 W/m2 (laser power at approximately 0.1 mW and laser spot size at 0.64 µm2).
2.3 Thermal transport measurement
The Rc between the VACNT array-heat sink interface was implemented by the adaptable
interfacial thermosensor-based 3ω (AIT-3ω) technique [22] developed by us. Compared with the conventional phase sensitive transient thermoreflectance (PSTTR) technique [4] and photothermal experimental technique [14] for Rc measurement, our technique is able to detect the pressure-dependence of Rc at the nanoscale interface, which is extremely interesting for the analysis of the quantitative ITT between VACNT array top and heat sink. A typical experimental setup is shown in Fig. 2a. The VACNT array on a diced SiO2/Si wafer was fixed onto a sample holder while the AIT is attached to a movable stage which can be shifted down to contact with the array top. The AIT composed of a 200 nm thick Au strip with four contact pads deposited on a thermally insulated substrate with silicon nitride (Si3N4) nanofilm as an interfacial layer. Most of the Joule heat released from the alternating current electric-heated Au strip will diffuse into the VACNT array after passing through the Si3N4 nanofilm. A small temperature rise T∆ occurs in the gold strip, which can be calculated by using the first (V1ω)
and third harmonic voltages (V3ω) using the equation ω ω 3 1 2 V V

where P” is the applied power density (W/m2), j is imaginary unit, and 2ω is the angular frequency of the heat flux (rad/s). Rc denotes the thermal contact resistance between the AIT and CNT array top surface (m2 K/W). Z is the thermal impedance (m2 K/W) and is expressed as ( ) jCωRωZ += −− 11 . For the VACNT array, the thermal resistance is defined by RCNT = l/κ
and thermal capacitance by C = ρcl/2. For semi-infinite medium, including the substrate of AIT and SiO2/Si wafer for supporting VACNT array, the thermal resistance and thermal capacitance can be expressed as ( )ωρcκR 1= and ( )ωρcκC 4= , respectively. Here ρ is
the density, c represents the specific heat, and l is the thickness of the corresponding media. Sensitivity analysis ( ( ) / /x d T T S dx x ∆ ∆= ) of Rc, C and κ exhibits significantly different evolutional trends with different frequencies (shown in Fig. 2b). It is clearly seen that Rc possesses a remarkably higher Sx especially in the high frequency region. Rc is first calculated based on the high-frequency T∆ data. Next, by setting the known value of Rc into the calculation model, C and κ can be determined sequentially. This data analysis scheme can ensure an optimized fitting accuracy and efficiency for the extraction of multiple uncertain variables. The thermal conductivity of MWCNT array (κCNT), specific heat (cCNT) and the Rc at CNTAIT interface were obtained by least-squares fitting of the experimental T∆ data with the
theoretical prediction ～ T∆ (Fig. 2c-i). Note that an optimal pressure was pre-determined and used during the measurements. According to our previous results on thermal resistance evolution with loading pressure,[8,23] the thermal contact resistance will appreciably decrease
M AN
US CR
IP T

CE
PT ED
with the increasing applied pressure but no longer decrease when the applied pressure is greater than 127 kPa. SEM images confirmed that under this pressure, the CNT array can return to original vertically aligned configuration once the pressure is withdrawn due to its good mechanical resilience (Fig. 3). Therefore, we took 127 kPa as the optimal pressure for our test structure and conditions. The pressure applied during the measurement was monitored in real-time by a group of FSR402 force sensitive detectors placed strategically around the bottom of the substrate (Fig. 2a), in order to ensure a reliable contact between CNTs and AIT therefore providing a reliable measurement.
Fig. 2. a) Schematic diagram of the adaptable interfacial thermosensor-based 3ω technique for thermal measurement of thermal contact resistance (Rc) between TiN/DLC-coated VACNT arrays and heat sink. b) Sensitivities of temperature amplitude signal ( T∆ ) to Rc, heat capacity (C) and thermal conductivity (κ). The experimental data and fitting results for c) uncoated VACNT array, d,e) TiN-coated VACNT arrays with 20 and 30 min deposition time respectively, and f-i) DLC-coated VACNT arrays with 15, 30, 45 and 60 min deposition time respectively.

Based on the above method, the thermophysical parameters of no-coating CNT array
were first fitted out for comparison and verification. The Rc, c and κ for the raw CNT array are 3.2 mm2 K/W, 585 J/kg K and 58.2 W/m K. The fitted c is within a reasonable range of specific heat of CNTs (500 ~ 740 J/kg K) at 300 K,[11,24-26] which confirms that our specific heat value obtained by AIT-3ω technique combined with the data fitting is reliable.

sections.heading: 3. Results and Discussions
sections.text:
3.1 Microscopic morphologies and structures
Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) imaging confirmed that DLC coatings manage to
fully cover the whole CNT walls instead of only the CNT tips (Fig. 4a-d). When the deposition time increases, more DLC coatings accumulated on the upper section of CNTs and form a continuous layer of coating. Statistical analysis of the heights of CNTs showed that there is no significant increase with increased DLC deposition timings. However, diameter distributions for the top and bottom of the CNT arrays clearly indicated that majority of the DLC coating is accumulating around the CNTs. Therefore, it is reasonable to propose that a longer DLC deposition time will lead to a larger circumferential thickness of the coated CNTs on the top than at the bottom. In marked contrast, TiN can more easily form a continuous layer on top of the CNT arrays (Fig. 4e,f). However, it is noted that a longer deposition time does not produce an obvious increase in the TiN coating thickness. Energy-dispersive X-ray
CR
IP T
spectrometer (EDX) data confirms the relevant elements exists on the exterior of the CNTs (Fig. 4g,h). Using a gray-scale line scanning method with Matlab® code based on the SEM images, the packing density for our samples was calculated to be as high as 7.5 × 109 CNTs/cm2, exceeding that obtained by Duke University’s Nanomaterials and Thin Films Lab and is comparable with data by Hinds et al,[27,28]. This strongly suggests that our novel structures are able to realize a larger contact area and hence lowers the Rc.
The CNTs are approximately 200 nm in diameter and typically wall to wall space is
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
approximately 0.32-0.35 nm (most common 0.34 nm) which is a mixture between high quality and defective CNTs, which is the fundamental reason for the broad peak in Raman spectrum (Fig. 5a,b). There are some folds at the nanotube wall, which makes it difficult to accurately determine the number of walls. In addition, the number of walls in the middle of CNTs and the bottom of the CNTs is different with the tip of the CNTs having less walls due to the encapsulation of the walls along the CNTs from bottom (more walls) to top (less walls). TEM micrographs further proves that the TiN nanocrystals and amorphous DLC were homogeneously coated along the exterior wall of the CNTs (Fig. 5c,e), reinforcing the possible decrease of thermal contact resistance. The corresponding selected area electron diffraction (SAED) (inset in Fig. 5c) shows diffraction rings which corresponds to (220), (111) and (200) crystallographic planes, which suggests that there may not be an obvious orientation for the TiN layer growth although the (200) plane possesses the smallest surface energy among the planes for TiN.[29] It is proposed that the ion bombardment during FCVA deposition produced a certain injection effect which caused the lattice distortion for the TiN layer and generated a certain stress, hence the (111) plane with the smallest strain energy also become a preferentially growth.[30] Figure 5d shows the clear lattice fringes with d spacing of 0.8164 and 0.8658 nm, which can be ascribed to the (511) and (422) crystal plane of TiN nanocrystals in the interior of the innermost CNTs. In contrast, the DLC coating was an amorphous structure material (Fig. 5f).
M
AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
Fig. 5. TEM micrographs showing morphologies of CNT picked up from arrays with (a) raw CNT (c) DLC coating and (e) TiN coating. According to the diffraction pattern of reciprocal space in the inset of Figure (b), the wall spacing is 0.34 nm. Figure (b), (d) and the selected area electron diffraction (SAED) images in Figure (c) and (e) show the lattice planes of CNT coated with crystalline and amorphous structure materials respectively.
3.2 Raman spectra analysis
The crystallinity and alignment of the coated CNT arrays must also be taken into
consideration because a high mismatch of anharmonic phonons from different species of materials can considerably impact the array-heat sink interfacial phonons transport.[31,32] A Renishaw InVia Raman spectroscopy apparatus operating with 532/633/785 nm lasers were used for Raman spectra analysis of DLC and TiN-coated VACNT arrays. The selected measurement positions were along the axial direction of the CNTs since it was difficult to determine the measurement positions from the top perspective. Two characteristic peaks (G peak and D peak) were clearly seen from the Raman measurement. The G mode has E2g
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
symmetry and its eigenvector involves the in-plane bond-stretching motion of pairs of C sp2 atoms. The D peak is a breathing mode of A1g symmetry involving phonons near the K zone boundary and only becomes active in the presence of disorder. It should be noted that the remarkable broadening of disorder peak (D peak) occurred for DLC-coated arrays, which is correlated to a distribution of carbon clusters with different orders and dimensions of the DLC layer.[33] In contrast, the D peak for TiN-coated arrays neither show the broadening nor a lowfrequency shoulder of the G peak. The D peak position for both DLC and TiN-coated arrays was varying with photon excitation energy (εL) when the G peak position was not dispersive (Fig. 6a,b). Furthermore, the D-band Raman shift frequencies versus εL data were well fitted by straight lines. The slopes of L εω ∂∂ for DLC and TiN-coated VACNT arrays (47 and 41 cm-1/eV) were close to that for sp2 carbon materials (51 cm-1/eV[32], Fig. 6c), such as PPP2400, glassy carbon, CNT assemblies. This confirms that the group velocity of the transverseacoustic phonon branch (υTA) for both DLC and TiN-coated VACNT arrays was
approximately the same according to the relation Lε
ω γa
q
ω υ ∂ ∂= ∂ ∂= 00TA 3 ∆ , where △q denotes
wavevectors, a0 is the in-plane graphite lattice constant (2.46 Å), and γ0 ≈ 3.0 eV is the nearest-neighbor C-C overlap energy.[32] This important result strongly suggests that our coating will not significantly deteriorate the phonon transmission within the array structures. Therefore, it is reasonable to propose that the coated VACNT array is still able to retain the high thermal transport ability like the uncoated counterpart, which is a great merit for nTIM application.
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
Fig. 6. Raman spectra of (a) DLC-coated and (b) TiN-coated VACNT arrays obtained with laser wavelengths 532 nm (2.44 eV), 633 nm (2.05 eV) and 785 nm (1.66 eV), showing remarkable broadening of D peaks. (c) Dependence of the frequencies of the D band on laser energy (εL) for DLC/TiN-coated VACNT arrays and sp2 carbon materials. (d,e) Schematic variations of the G position and ID/IG ratio.
With the increasing deposition time of DLC, more sp2 sites from CNTs become more
prone to cluster in a sp3 matrix in DLC. When sp2 configuration changes from rings to olefinic (C=C) groups, the G peak position increases (Fig. 6d), because shorter olefinic bonds possess a higher vibrational frequency than aromatic bonds. The maximum intensity ratio for the D peak to the G peak, i.e., ID/IG, was used for the crystallinity analysis. ID/IG increases with increasing disorder originating from larger clusters inside the sputtered DLC, according to a quantitative mathematical expression proposed by Tuinstra and Koening (TK).[34,35] Therefore, with the elongating deposition of DLC and TiN, more disordering appears for the coated VACNT arrays. When compared to DLC, the deposition of TiN leads to a larger ID/IG (Fig. 6e), which well explains why a slight reduction of υTA occurs after coating (Fig. 6c). Our Raman spectroscopy characterization results show that the thermal transport of individual
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
CNTs within the arrays is maintained when coatings are adhered to CNTs. Thus, the intrinsic thermal transport of the CNT arrays with DLC/TiN coating is a good method that maintains an excellent heat conduction performance of CNT arrays and yet improves the contact resistance between the arrays and heat sink.
3.3 Thermal contact resistance of coated VACNT array-heat sink interface
The sample of VACNT array covered with DLC (DLC 45min) is used to illustrate the
calculation procedure for Rc. A 200 nm thick Au strip in the AIT is used as heater and sensor. The in-between length is 8 mm and the width is 40 µm. Using a sinusoidal current with frequency ω to heat the Au strip, a series of corresponding V1ω and V3ω can be obtained by changing the measurement frequency. The driving current is 0.022 A, and V1ω in this measurement is basically unchanged at 2.75 V, then the applied power density P” in Eq. (1) can be calculated as 189.06 kW/m2. The P” values for other samples can be calculated according to the data in Table 1. The calculation of the experimental temperature rise uses the
equation 3

temperature coefficient of resistance αCR of Au is 0.004 /K, [5] and the experimental temperature rise at every test frequency can be obtained using this equation. The experimental T∆ is shown as circles in Fig. 2h. Up to this step, T∆ and P” in Eq. (1) has been determined. RCNT =l/κ, where l represents the thickness of the VACNT, which is 6.4 µm as measured from the SEM image in Fig. 4c. The thermal conductivity κ is the parameter to be determined. Since the VACNT is grown on the SiO2/Si wafer, the thermal impedance of the wafer Zwafer ( ( ) jCωRωZ += −− 11 ) needs to be taken into account in the theoretical temperature rise model.
The density ρ, specific heat c and thermal conductivity κ for SiO2/Si wafer are summarized in Table 2. The corresponding values of thermal resistance R and thermal capacitance C can be

calculated based on ( )ωρcκR 1= and ( )ωρcκC 4= . The thermal impedance of the AIT
substrate (PMMA) Zsub. is calculated in the same way as Zwafer. The last item that needs to be determined is the specific heat c, which is included in thermal capacitance CCNT (C = ρcl/2). The density of CNT in this work is 1830 kg/m3. At this point, all the parameters in Eq. (1) are clear. According to the sensitivity analysis of the three parameters to frequency in Fig. 2b, Rc is fist fitted based on a least-squares fitting algorithm for it has the highest Sx especially in the high frequency region. The second parameter to be determined is c according to the magnitude of Sx. Thermal conductivity κ which is the least sensitive to frequencies is calculated at last.

SiO2/Si wafer 2230 800 1.1 PMMA 1188 1450 0.19
The thermal contact resistance between VACNT array top surface and heat sink was
found to considerably shrink to 0.3 mm2 K/W for the VACNT array coated with DLC (DLC 30min) owing to extremely large average diameter on top surface (d ≈ 525 nm) and low
height relative standard deviation (RSD defined by △l/l ≈ 0.13). It is clearly seen that Rc for
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
coated VACNT array-heat sink interface was much lower than that of uncoated counterpart (Fig. 7a), which can be explained by the sharp rise of the diameters of VACNT array at the top surface after coating. Moreover, it is intriguing to note that the linear dependence of Rc on the height RSD become weaker as compared to VACNT arrays synthesized by floating catalyst chemical vapor deposition (FCCVD) method.[8] This is probably due to the fact that the sharp rise in CNT diameters obscures the role of height RSD in influencing the Rc. Although VACNT arrays synthesized by FCCVD possess relatively lower height RSD, the small CNT diameters restrain them from attaining a low Rc. In contrast, our coated arrays can cut down Rc by 50 times, i.e., 15 mm 2 K/W for uncoated VACNT arrays from FCCVD synthesis versus 0.3 mm2 K/W for DLC-coated VACNT arrays from PECVD. Such a huge shrinkage can be majorly ascribed to the enlarged diameters from the PECVD process and further enlarged by DLC coatings. Note that identical samples fabricated through PECVD without coating still hold a relatively high Rc, up to 3.7 mm 2 K/W. Therefore, additional coatings such as DLC and TiN are necessary to achieve a lower Rc in order for effective use in nTIM application.
Fig. 7. (a) Dependence on the RSD of array height (∆l/l, where ∆l equals to the statistical absolute height deviation and l is the height) for thermal contact resistances (Rc) at CNT-sensor interface. When the effect of height deviation is cancelled out, the distinct Rc values originate from the vast difference in the CNT
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
diameters caused by different synthesis approaches (our samples: PECVD and DLC/TiN coating, control samples[8]: FCCVD and no coating). (b) Comparison among Rc of various VACNT arrays from previous reports and this study.
We further perform comparative studies of the Rc of various VACNT arrays from
previous reports and this study. It is clearly seen that either DLC or TiN coatings can greatly improve the interfacial contact condition for VACNT array top contacting with heat sink (Fig. 7b), i.e., approximately tens of times of reduction in Rc from averaged 10 mm 2 K/W[4,12-15,3638] to 0.3 mm2 K/W. According to the above analysis, it is the enlarged thermal contact area due to the introduction of coatings that promotes the interfacial thermal transport for arrayheat sink interface, thus successfully reduces Rc down to a magnitude of the equivalent thermal resistance of the VACNT arrays (0.1~0.4 mm2 K/W). Therefore, future effort towards designing and fabricating of high-efficiency VACNT array-based nTIM should be centered on coated arrays with lower thermal contact resistance at potential CNT-heat sink interface. Such improvement measure enables a remarkable boost of interfacial thermal transport for CNT nTIM-heat sink contacts. Enlargement of CNT diameters via PECVD synthesis and extra coatings on the top of the CNT arrays have been confirmed to be of paramount importance for thrusting practical application of VACNT arrays as efficient nTIM for microelectronics and related thermal management fields.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
In summary, this study reports a novel quantitative comparison of the thermal contact
resistances Rc of VACNT array-heat sink interfaces from two main-stream VACNT array synthesis approaches, i.e., PECVD and FCCVD, and additional coatings on top of CNT arrays as compared to its uncoated counterpart. According to the measurement results for Rc, this study demonstrates that DLC and TiN-coated PECVD-synthesized CNT arrays possess
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
excellent interfacial thermal transport characteristics when interfaced with heat sink. In marked contrast to the conventionally reported Rc on the order of 10 mm 2 K/W, our DLC and TiN-coated VACNT arrays exhibit an extremely low Rc down to 0.3 mm 2 K/W, a significantly breakthrough for nTIM application. This drastic reduction in Rc by using coated PECVD-synthesized VACNT array is mainly attributed to the larger CNT diameters therefore increasing the contact area, which remarkably favors interfacial thermal transport from VACNT array to the heat sink. Furthermore, it is intriguing to note that Rc no longer follows the linear dependence on CNT height deviation once CNT diameters become large enough (hundreds of nanometers). This suggests that the surface roughness of CNT arrays plays a lesser role as compared to the contact area with heat sink in influencing the magnitude of Rc. The above findings fuel future effort towards realizing industrial application of highperformance VACNT array-based nTIM and high-efficiency thermal management in microelectronic and nanoenergy fields.

metadata.abstractText: The interfacial thermal transport (ITT) between vertically aligned carbon nanotube (VACNT) arrays and heat sink is the dominant barrier blocking the path towards practical application of VACNT arrays as nano-thermal interface materials (nTIMs). Although developing VACNT arrays with homogeneous heights and larger diameters could lower the thermal contact resistance between the arrays and heat sink (Rc), little effect is achieved at present stage. Here, by using Plasma Enhanced Chemical Vapor Deposition approach, we attain DLC/TiN-coated VACNT arrays, which gives up to 50 times reduction in Rc from 15 mm 2 K/W to 0.3 mm K/W. Microscopic morphological analyses confirm that the remarkably expanded contact area brought by coatings can promote the ITT and also retain the high phonon transmission rate within individual CNTs. These novel structures are significantly in favor of fulfilling a nTIM function. It is also intriguing to note that Rc is no longer linearly dependent on CNT height variations once CNT diameters become large M AN US CR IP T AC CE PT ED ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
